conclusion: Principles of shadow formation: shadow length decreases as light source moves upward, shadow direction shifts closer to objects, and shadow size decreases.
The image shows four objects (an apple, a cloth, a transparent object, and a drumstick) casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D respectively.
The shadows A, B, C, and D are positioned directly under their respective objects due to the current position of the light source.
When the light source moves upward, the distance between the light source and the objects increases.
As the light source moves upward, the shadows will become shorter because the light rays become more vertical, reducing the spread of the shadow on the ground.
The shadows will shift closer to the objects as the light source moves upward, causing the light rays to align more directly downward.
The size of the shadows will decrease due to the increased distance and angle of the light source.
When the light source moves upward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will decrease in length, shift closer to the objects, and decrease in size.
